text: scones sometimes they can be
disappointing a real kitchen conundrum
but today I'm going to show you how to
avoid those dense dry crumbly scones
like the one I have here and make light
and fluffy scones that you will love to
start I'm going to use a mixture of
flour so I have in front of me cake
flour and all-purpose flour now I'm
using a blend of cake flour because cake
flour has a lower protein content than
all-purpose flour so what does that mean
well ultimately it will give you a
lighter more tender scone so I have 1
cup of cake flour here and I'm going to
use 2 cups of all-purpose flour now you
don't want to scoop into the jar of
flour here because what that does is it
compacts the flour and you'll get a
different quantity of flour in your cup
so always follow this method and I'm
going to sift the flour just to make
sure there are no clumps also helps to
aerate the flour to lighten the mixture
so that's 2 cups of all-purpose flour
and 1/2 a cup of sugar just going to
sift this mixture together into a large
bowl so one of the secrets to making
really wonderful light and fluffy scones
is having cold ingredients what you need
is chilled butter so I have one and a
half cups of unsalted butter that I've
cut into tiny little cubes and it's icy
cold what it does is it creates tiny
little pea-sized pieces of butter and
what that does is in the oven the butter
melts and it creates steam and that
steam is what creates the flaky layers
for your scone pour this flour mixture
right into my food processor here now if
you didn't have a food processor no
worries you can use one of these this is
a pastry blender and what it does is it
cuts the butter into those nice size
pieces avoiding your hands in contact
with the butter which melts the butter
warms it up so into the food processor
I'm going to add two teaspoons of baking
powder 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda
and of course you always need a little
bit of salt when you're baking so 3/4 of
a teaspoon of coarse salt and so I'm
going to pulse this mixture together
evenly distributing the lemon or with
the flour and the sugar
and now I'm going to add the fat which
is one and a half sticks of unsalted
butter and you're going to pulse this
together until you get three sized
pieces of the butter so this looks good
you can see the pea sized pieces of
butter they're slightly different sizes
but that's totally fine so now your
flour fat mixture here goes right back
into that large bowl that you had sifted
everything into now if you were doing
this by hand and the butter starts to
warm up at this point you can put this
mixture into the refrigerator until the
butter is nice and cold remember it's
very important to keep the fat really
really cold to get those flaky scones
now the butter is still nice and cold
I'm going to create a well in my bowl
here then add a quarter teaspoon of
vanilla extract right to Mike one and a
quarter cups of heavy cream the cream is
gonna go right into the center of my
well and at this point you want to
gently mix everything together you don't
want to aggressively stir this because
what that's gonna do is it's gonna
develop the gluten in the flour and it's
gonna give you a very tough crumbly
scone that's not what you want here you
want something that's really really
light so just until the mixture comes
together it can kind of be a shaggy mess
like it is right now and this goes onto
a lightly floured surface and what
you're going to do this is a plastic
bowl scraper you could use a bench
scraper you can use a spatula if that's
what you have you're going to gently
knead and fold the shaggy dough into
itself compressing the dough into one
kind of cohesive mass so now I'm going
to Pat this out into approximately eight
by thirteen inch rectangle and this is
something that will really help you get
a nice flaky puffy scone it's called
laminating and it's similar to what is
done with puff pastry or croissant dough
those are laminated dough's laminated
dough's means that there's layers we're
kind of folding up the layers to create
even more puff
so what I'm going to do is I'm going to
take the two short ends and I'm going to
fold them in on themselves now you can
do this two times so folding it like
this and then again maybe a little bit
more flour patting it out into another 8
by 13 inch rectangle now you want to
make sure that you don't create a
rectangle that's too too flat so you
want about an inch and a quarter in
height of your dough and this looks
pretty good to me
so I have a two and a quarter inch
biscuit cutter here and you can lightly
flour your cutter
whenever you're punching biscuits or
scones you want to make sure that you
punch and you don't twist the biscuit
cutter because what that does is it
seals off the sides which inhibits the
rise so just go straight down into your
dough and then these go right onto a
parchment lined baking sheet now I have
a little extra cream brush just the tops
of the scones with the cream you don't
want any of the cream to fall down the
sides because what that will do is it
will inhibit the rising so just the tops
here now for a little bit of crunch and
maybe a little bit of sparkle on top of
your scones I have some fine sanding
sugar here you can use regular
granulated sugar if you don't have fine
sanding sugar and so these go right into
the oven 375 degrees for about 18 to 20
minutes you want to rotate halfway
through so that they're perfectly even
golden brown in color so the scones are
out of the oven there's still a little
bit warm but you can see they puffed up
they're nice and light scones they
shouldn't be heavy for their size and I
can't wait even though this is a little
bit warm I'm going to try one of these
guys you know you can serve them up with
a little bit of butter or you can use
Jam and as always guys if you have any
baking conundrums or kitchen conundrums
write in the comment section below or
reach out to me using the hashtag
kitchen conundrum
and I will solve whatever problems you
throw my way enjoy guys
